reviewText:
I was really surprised by this game, Signal Studios and Krome Studios have definitely stepped up the offering from previous games. I love the maps, lots of foliage and open terrain, with beautifully designed structures. The eight armies all have something different and unique to offer, the game IMO is a good complement to owners of Toy Soldiers Complete, love the new look and design. I have this game for PS4 and PC, PS4 is more colorful and cartoonish to a degree than the PC version, though on a good rig, PC looks more intricate and detailed, it's a preference thing, some will like one version over the other. The graphics and unit designs in this game are infinitely better than previous offerings of Toy Soldiers games, by far, this is the best looking game in the series to date. Sound effects on headphones is great, and when playing on my Logitech Z-5500s, some of the anti-personnel weapons should be more defined and powerful sounding, though they still sound great.

The progression map and unlock of unique units and traits is a great approach, you can pick a faction and level it up throughout an open progression campaign map, nice touch. Overall, I highly recommend this game, seeing the Joes, He-Man and others battle it out on beautifully designed maps and levels is a joyous sight to be had. Hope to see more content added to this game in the future, want more of it, it's that good!

I've played mostly on console, just picked up the PC version, playing on an i7-920 stock, Gigabyte G1 970 at 2560x1440 all video card settings and in game maxed with zero issues so far, Windows 10 OS. Of note, some of the troops on the turrets do odd things I've noticed, I'm mostly using Phantom and I noticed some of the individual troops on your turrets are not even firing at the enemy, they are just randomly firing off into nowhere, a little disconcerting, more of an immersion breaker, than anything else. reviewText:
Introduction:
I have played the other two Toy Soldier game(Xbox) and enjoyed them a lot. They were very close to perfect and the second one was a clear step forward for the series. Toy Soldier War Chest falls shorter than either of those games to perfection and I feel it doesn’t grow the series at all.

General Thoughts:
War Chest is a lot of fun it uses the formula that the other two games built but does do all that much different from the other two games. The hero mechanic has been expanded where you have a kill-streak like bar. As you get more kills in the turret that you’re using the bar will go up unlocking hero, vehicle, and then super weapon for you to use. Each race has unique turrets animations, models and has some slight differences in rate of fire and range. Heroes have unique and fun weapons but the dlc heroes don’t have as many as the base game heroes when it comes to weapons. Heroes also can’t jump this is a flaw and really should have been added. Other than those features the game plays the same as the other to titles in the franchise. It has weekly invasions(challenges) which are fun and will expand the gameplay slightly.

The Bad:
Having a sequel that doesn’t grow the franchise isn’t always bad if they improve what’s there. War Chest doesn’t, it plays like the other two but now heroes are harder to control. It’s annoying but not 100% bad when it comes to the hero’s controls although I would highly recommend a controller. The other two toy soldier’s games had a unique fun war theme with them. War Chest is fun but that war theme is no longer there really, so if you wanted that feeling you won’t find it here. There is a in game shop. This does have micro transactions, but you can unlock anything with coins you will earn in the game. You get the coins fairly and I feel they added just of those that are impatience with getting unlocks.

The Good:
It plays as well as the other two games(excluding heroes) with fun level design that will give you a challenge. It’s a fun game and you’re looking for a good tower defense game with some third-person components you will find it here. The upgrading for turrents have been sighlty improved now you can upgrade different parts individually. (range,damage,armor)

The Meh:

Uplay, it’s here, it isn’t as bad as I thought it would be. It took only about 5 minutes to set up and I have had no problem with it when in game. It does take a couple extra minutes for the game to start though. The menu is bare bones its only what you really need and not much else.

Final thoughts:
Even with its flaws it’s a fun and good game in the series. I would recommend it to you on sale. If you like tower defense games and need something to scratch that itch this will do it for you.

reviewText:
It's a really fun game. There are some bugs and things to iron out, but I don't regret my purchase one bit.

A lot of lemmings are throwing around a bunch of entitled gamer cliches to disparage the game, but let's look at the complaints:

30fps lock.

So what? This isn't CS or some other twitch shooter. The game looks good and plays smoothly.

Day 1 DLC.

Look, I think there is something wrong with forcing people to pay for a map or weapon pack Day 1. That stuff should be packaged in with the base game. But that's not really what's going on here. They released a very cheap game ($15) and are simply asking you to pay a little extra money if you want to play licensed IPs such as GI-JOE and He-Man. Being able to play with classic IPs is one of the main attractions of the game, and you can't do that without paying for the IPs. That costs money, which has to come from somewhere. Either play the base game with in-house IPs or pony up and pay an extra $15–not an exorbitant price at all–to play with licensed IPs. Seems fair.

Microtransactions.

I haven't found anything in the game that can't be purchased with tokens that you gain by simply playing the game. The game isn't P2W; it just gives you an option to save time by purchasing rather than farming tokens. You're not forced into microtransactions, and microtransactions allow the game to be released at a lower price point. It's a win-win: People can pay money to accelerate token accrual and people who don't purchase tokens benefit from a cheaper game.
TL;DR: The game is fun, and people are getting their panties in a bunch for no reason.

I was a big fan of the previous titles in the series, even though I have been anxiously awaiting numerous updates for the complete edition, but now with seeing this title I guess I can understand why it's taken them so long.

The game is tower defense with heavy empahsis on action and actually controlling the towers to mow down the incoming hordes. You build in limited places, upgrade and control the towers at your pleasure.

So how does this compare to the previous Toy Soldiers...
1. Obvious one here. Instead of just 'realistic' toy soldiers you do battle with different toy sets. One of the charms of the first game for me was the existential battle of fighting another army in a child like, mass destruction/killing for fun sort of way. With the fantasy elements obviously that dynamic is a little different.

2. Unlike the first game where you progress through stages to unlock upgrades for the overall towers, here you unlock different indivdual tower elements (range,power, etc) for the towerswith coins or random drops at the end of the level. This means a lot of grinding which was present in the previous games as well. But now with 7 or whatever sets of characters, that's a lot of playing maps over and over. And again although they are asthetically very different, as of now I don't see much variation in the actual functionality of the towers.

3. Every time you level up your different toy sets, you recieve these things that look like pogs. They are the individual upgrades for the turrets. You can also purchase boxes of the random upgrades as well.

3. There is a new weekly challenge mode. That's cool and helps with the grinding aspect.

4. Day one DLC. Yeah pretty lame. Be aware that even though the DLC packs are for Heman, ♥♥♥ Creed and whatever...Those character sets are available to play in the vanilla game. Purchasing the DLC packs just offers additonal toys as part of that set. For example with Masters of the Universe one of the things you get is that bad ♥♥♥ tiger thing for He Man to ride.

So far I am enjoying it. I will update the review later once I have put in some more hours and (hopefully) get to play some online co-op.

I really enjoyed this game the 30 fps lock didn't effect me and it ran well for on my rig I don't see any problem with this I never drop below 30. while people were complaining about Uplay I only saw good in the program other than DRM which I can see people fight over aka the offline player but still does not take any thing from the game but adds new great features like using those usless Uplay points for example buy coins or weapons for you're selected faction like a goldplated minigun example which you can only get from Uplay.

PROS
-4 different teams for the base game that have different themed units and different hero's.
-Fun gameplay with many different weapons for you hero's.
-Great detail to animation for towers that make them feel more alive
-Runs fine

CONS
-Different team towers are almost baiscally the same with different themes and animations on them.
-DRM
-Dlc's like cobra and assassin's creed feel the same like the uther dlcs like He-man and G.J Joes but I enjoyed them both .
-Short campaign with but has survival mpas to add to you're play time.
-Some cliping with the models but I didn't mind it.
-Fly is really bad for turning be warned.

Over all the game is worth the money I spent on it and I would rate it a 8/10 But since the game still has flaws it doesn't make it a bad game but a rushed game that just need alittle polishing.
